Angles

1. Sum of angles in polygons

Polygon identification

Study the polygon below and answer the questions that follow:

Answer:
  1. Name the polygon:
  2. What is the sum of the interior angles of this polygon? °°
string
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
The answers to both questions depend on the number of sides of the polygon. Start by counting the sides.
STEP: Identify the polygon by the number of sides
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We name polygons based on how many sides they have. The diagram in this question shows a polygon with 1010 sides. This polygon is called a decagon.

STEP: Determine the sum of the interior angles with the formula 180°(n−2)180°(n−2)
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

We can determine the sum of the interior angles of a polygon based on how many sides it has using the formula: 180°(n−2)180°(n−2) where nn is the number of sides. A decagon has 1010 sides, so:

Let n be the number of sides∴n=10Sum of Interior angles of a polygonSum of Interior angles of a decagon=180°(n−2)=180°×((10)−2)=180°×(8)=1440°Let n be the number of sides∴n=10Sum of Interior angles of a polygon=180°(n−2)=180°×((10)−2)=180°×(8)Sum of Interior angles of a decagon=1440°
NOTE: The angle indicated in the figure is the sum of all the angles, not an individual angle.

The formula we are using actually finds out into how many triangles this polygon is divided. The interior angles of a triangle have a sum of 180°180°. So 180°×8=1440°180°×8=1440°.

The name of this polygon is decagon and the sum of the interior angles of a decagon is 1440°1440°.

Isosceles triangles

Determine the value of zz, giving a reason for your answer.

Answer: z=z= mmmm (())
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You are given a triangle with two equal angles. The sides opposite those angles will be equal.

STEP: Apply isosceles triangle reasons
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to know two geometry facts about isosceles triangles:

  1. If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite those sides will be equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  2. If two angles in a triangle are equal, then the sides opposite those angles will be equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).

The information on the diagram shows that ∠P=∠Q∠P=∠Q. In other words, two angles of the triangle are equal. So, the sides opposite these angles will be equal.

z=19 mm(sides opp equal ∠s)z=19 mm(sides opp equal ∠s)
NOTE: It can be challenging to figure out which of the two reasons to use. In this question we are looking for a side. So, we use the reason that starts with sides: "sides opp equal ∠∠s".

numeric
numeric

[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Think about the triangle and parallel line reasons that we have learned so far:

  • The interior angles of a triangle add up to 180° (sum of ∠∠s in ΔΔ).
  • The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  • The angles opposite the equal sides in an isosceles triangle are equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  • The sides opposite the equal angles in an isosceles triangle are equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).
  • Corresponding angles on parallel lines are equal (corresp ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).
  • Alternate angles on parallel lines are equal (alt ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).
  • Co-interior angles on parallel lines add up to 180° (co-int ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).
STEP: Determine the size of xx
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

Think about the triangle and parallel line reasons that we have learned so far:

  • sum of ∠∠s in ΔΔ
  • ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ
  • ∠∠s opp equal sides
  • sides opp equal ∠∠s
  • corresp ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD
  • alt ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD
  • co-int ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD

We can see that xx is an exterior angle of the triangle because CDCD is an extension of a side of the triangle.

The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles.

x∴x=54°+50°(ext ∠ of Δ)=104°x=54°+50°(ext ∠ of Δ)∴x=104°

This is also the quickest way to answer the question.

Overlapping triangles

In the diagram below, JLJL = JNJN.

Determine the sizes of vv and ww, giving reasons for your answers.

Answer: v=v= °°
w=w= °°
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]
  1. The sum of the interior angles in a triangle is 180°180° (sum of ∠∠s in ΔΔ).
  2. The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  3. If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite those sides will be equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  4. If two angles in a triangle are equal, then the sides opposite those angles will be equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).

If none of these work, think about other reasons that you've learnt. The triangle facts may be useful after you've found vv.

STEP: Determine the size of vv
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

When we see a geometry question we should think about all of the geometry reasons that we have learned, and identify which one of these facts links vv with angles that we already know. The triangle reasons are:

  1. The sum of the interior angles in a triangle is 180°180° (sum of ∠∠s in ΔΔ).
  2. The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  3. If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite those sides will be equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  4. If two angles in a triangle are equal, then the sides opposite those angles will be equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).

If we look at ΔJLNΔJLN, we can see that ∠JLN∠JLN is equal to ∠N∠N, since they are angles opposite equal sides in ΔJLNΔJLN.

∠JLN∴v+40°∴v+40°−40°∴v=∠N(∠s opp equal sides)=73°=73°−40°=33°∠JLN=∠N(∠s opp equal sides)∴v+40°=73°∴v+40°−40°=73°−40°∴v=33°
STEP: Determine the size of ww
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now that we have determined the size of vv, we can use sum of angles in ΔJLNΔJLN to determine the size of ww.

w+(33°+40°)+73°∴w+146°∴w+146°−146°∴w=180°(sum of ∠s in Δ)=180°=180−146°=34°w+(33°+40°)+73°=180°(sum of ∠s in Δ)∴w+146°=180°∴w+146°−146°=180−146°∴w=34°
NOTE: You might have tried to use sum of angles in ΔJLKΔJLK to determine ww. But there is not enough information to use this triangle, because we do not know the size of ∠NJK∠NJK.

Interior angles in quadrilaterals

In quadrilateral ABCDABCD below, Â =xA^=x, B̂ =229°B^=229°, Ĉ =45°C^=45°, and D̂ =41°D^=41°.

Determine the size of xx, giving a reason for your answer.

Answer: x=x= °°
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

What number do the interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to?

STEP: Remember that the interior angles of a quadrilateral add up to 360°360°
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
The interior angles in a quadrilateral add up to 360°360° (sum of ∠∠s in quad).

The interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to 360°360°. This is because any quadrilateral can always be divided into two triangles. The angles in a triangle add up to 180°180°, so the angles in two triangles add up as follows: 180°180° ++ 180°180° == 360°360°.

NOTE: You do not need to show this proof in your working out. It is just here so that you can see where the fact comes from.
STEP: Apply sum of angles in a quad to determine xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

x+229°+45°+41°=360°x+229°+45°+41°=360° (sum of ∠s in quad)(sum of ∠s in quad)

∴x+315°∴x+315°−315°∴x=360°=360°−315°=45°∴x+315°=360°∴x+315°−315°=360°−315°∴x=45°

  • If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite those sides will be equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).

∠A=57°(∠s opp equal sides)∠A=57°(∠s opp equal sides)
STEP: Determine the size of xx
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now that we know the size of ∠A∠A, we can use sum of angles in a triangle to calculate the value of xx:

x+57°+57°∴x+114°∴x+114°−114°∴x=180°(∠ sum in Δ)=180°=180°−114°=66°x+57°+57°=180°(∠ sum in Δ)∴x+114°=180°∴x+114°−114°=180°−114°∴x=66°
NOTE: You cannot work out the value of xx straight away, because there is not enough information. First you have to determine the size of ∠A∠A, using ∠∠s opp equal sides. Then, you can use ∠∠ sum in ΔΔ.

Think about the triangle and parallel line reasons that you have learned so far:

  • The interior angles of a triangle add up to 180°180° (∠∠ sum in ΔΔ).
  • The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  • The angles opposite the equal sides in an isosceles triangle are equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  • The sides opposite the equal angles in an isosceles triangle are equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).
  • Corresponding angles on parallel lines are equal (corresp ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM).
  • Alternate angles on parallel lines are equal (alt ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM).
  • Co-interior angles on parallel lines add up to 180°180° (co-int ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM).
STEP: Use the isosceles triangle to determine ∠LKM∠LKM

  • The interior angles of a triangle add up to 180°180° (∠∠ sum in ΔΔ).
  • The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).

Polygon identification

What kind of polygon is shown below?

Answer:

This polygon is a/an

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Polygons are named according to the number of sides that they have.

STEP: Name the polygon
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
A polygon is a closed shape made of straight lines. Closed means that one line follows another line until you get back to where you started.

We name polygons by the number of sides they have.

Number of sides Name
3 triangle
4 quadrilateral
5 pentagon
6 hexagon
7 heptagon
8 octagon
9 nonagon
10 decagon

This polygon has 55 sides, so it is called a pentagon.

We can determine the sum of the interior angles of a polygon based on how many sides it has using the formula: 180°(n−2)180°(n−2) where nn is the number of sides. A octagon has 88 sides, so:

The name of this polygon is octagon and the sum of the interior angles of a octagon is 1080°1080°.

  • The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).

  1. The sum of the interior angles in a triangle is 180°180° (sum of ∠∠s in ΔΔ).
  2. The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  3. If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite those sides will be equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  4. If two angles in a triangle are equal, then the sides opposite those angles will be equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).

If none of these work, think about other reasons that you've learnt. The triangle facts may be useful after you've found xx.

  2. The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  3. If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite those sides will be equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  4. If two angles in a triangle are equal, then the sides opposite those angles will be equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).

If we look at ΔBDAΔBDA, we can see that ∠BDA∠BDA is equal to ∠A∠A, since they are angles opposite equal sides in ΔBDAΔBDA.

Interior angles in quadrilaterals

In quadrilateral QRSTQRST below, Q̂ =73°Q^=73°, R̂ =113°R^=113°, Ŝ =xS^=x, and T̂ =71°T^=71°.

Determine the size of xx, giving a reason for your answer.

Answer: x=x= °°
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

What number do the interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to?

STEP: Remember that the interior angles of a quadrilateral add up to 360°360°
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
The interior angles in a quadrilateral add up to 360°360° (sum of ∠∠s in quad).

The interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to 360°360°. This is because any quadrilateral can always be divided into two triangles. The angles in a triangle add up to 180°180°, so the angles in two triangles add up as follows: 180°180° ++ 180°180° == 360°360°.

NOTE: You do not need to show this proof in your working out. It is just here so that you can see where the fact comes from.
STEP: Apply sum of angles in a quad to determine xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

73°+113°+x+71°=360°73°+113°+x+71°=360° (sum of ∠s in quad)(sum of ∠s in quad)

∴x+257°∴x+257°−257°∴x=360°=360°−257°=103°∴x+257°=360°∴x+257°−257°=360°−257°∴x=103°

What number do the interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to?

STEP: Remember that the interior angles of a quadrilateral add up to 360°360°
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
The interior angles in a quadrilateral add up to 360°360° (sum of ∠∠s in quad).

The interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to 360°360°. This is because any quadrilateral can always be divided into two triangles. The angles in a triangle add up to 180°180°, so the angles in two triangles add up as follows: 180°180° ++ 180°180° == 360°360°.

NOTE: You do not need to show this proof in your working out. It is just here so that you can see where the fact comes from.
STEP: Apply sum of angles in a quad to determine xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

x+230°+45°+45°=360°x+230°+45°+45°=360° (sum of ∠s in quad)(sum of ∠s in quad)

∴x+320°∴x+320°−320°∴x=360°=360°−320°=40°∴x+320°=360°∴x+320°−320°=360°−320°∴x=40°

Isosceles triangles: two-step solutions

Determine the size of zz, giving reasons for all statements.

INSTRUCTION: Answer the question by completing the statements below.
Answer: ∠F=∠F= °° (())
∴z=∴z= °° (())
numeric
numeric

[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

First use the fact that angles opposite equal sides in a triangle are equal, to determine the size of ∠F∠F.

STEP: Determine the size of ∠F∠F
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

When we see a triangle with equal sides, we should remember that:

  • If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite those sides will be equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).

This tells us that

∠F=70°(∠s opp equal sides)∠F=70°(∠s opp equal sides)
STEP: Determine the size of zz
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now that we know the size of ∠F∠F, we can use sum of angles in a triangle to calculate the value of zz:

z+70°+70°∴z+140°∴z+140°−140°∴z=180°(∠ sum in Δ)=180°=180°−140°=40°z+70°+70°=180°(∠ sum in Δ)∴z+140°=180°∴z+140°−140°=180°−140°∴z=40°

y+68°+68°∴y+136°∴y+136°−136°∴y=180°(∠ sum in Δ)=180°=180°−136°=44°y+68°+68°=180°(∠ sum in Δ)∴y+136°=180°∴y+136°−136°=180°−136°∴y=44°
NOTE: You cannot work out the value of yy straight away, because there is not enough information. First you have to determine the size of ∠P∠P, using ∠∠s opp equal sides. Then, you can use ∠∠ sum in ΔΔ.

STEP: Determine the size of ∠C∠C

Isosceles triangles and parallel lines

In the diagram below, AB∥CDAB∥CD and BC=CDBC=CD. Determine the size of ff, giving reasons for all statements.

NOTE: Often there is more than one correct way to answer a geometry question. You must answer this question by completing the statements below. Each step needs only one reason.
Answer: ∠CBD=∠CBD= °° (())
∴f=∴f= °° (())
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Think about the triangle and parallel line reasons that you have learned so far:

  • The interior angles of a triangle add up to 180°180° (∠∠ sum in ΔΔ).
  • The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  • The angles opposite the equal sides in an isosceles triangle are equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  • The sides opposite the equal angles in an isosceles triangle are equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).
  • Corresponding angles on parallel lines are equal (corresp ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).
  • Alternate angles on parallel lines are equal (alt ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).
  • Co-interior angles on parallel lines add up to 180°180° (co-int ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).
STEP: Use the isosceles triangle to determine ∠CBD∠CBD
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

Think about the triangle and parallel line reasons that you have learned so far:

  • The interior angles of a triangle add up to 180°180° (∠∠ sum in ΔΔ).
  • The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  • The angles opposite the equal sides in an isosceles triangle are equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  • The sides opposite the equal angles in an isosceles triangle are equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).
  • Corresponding angles on parallel lines are equal (corresp ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).
  • Alternate angles on parallel lines are equal (alt ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).
  • Co-interior angles on parallel lines add up to 180°180° (co-int ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD).

It is not possible to work out ff in one step, so we first have to determine the size of another angle: ∠CBD∠CBD.

We are told that BC=CDBC=CD in ΔBCDΔBCD, so we can use angles opposite equal sides to determine ∠CBD∠CBD.

∠CBD=48°(∠s opp equal sides)∠CBD=48°(∠s opp equal sides)
STEP: Use co-interior angles to determine ff
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now that we have ∠CBD∠CBD, we can use this to determine ff.

We can see that ∠ABD∠ABD is co-interior with ∠D∠D on the parallel lines.

(f+48°)+48°∴f+96°∴f+96°−96°∴f=180°(co-int ∠s; AB∥CD)=180°=180°−96°=84°(f+48°)+48°=180°(co-int ∠s; AB∥CD)∴f+96°=180°∴f+96°−96°=180°−96°∴f=84°
NOTE: You might have solved this step by using sum of angles in ΔBCDΔBCD and then alternate angles on parallel lines. If you included all of the reasons that you used, your teacher would mark this as correct. But, this step only has space for one reason, so it has to be co-int ∠∠s; AB∥CDAB∥CD. This is also the quickest way to answer the question.

Polygon identification

What kind of polygon is shown below?

Answer:

This polygon is a/an

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Polygons are named according to the number of sides that they have.

STEP: Name the polygon
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
A polygon is a closed shape made of straight lines. Closed means that one line follows another line until you get back to where you started.

We name polygons by the number of sides they have.

Number of sides Name
3 triangle
4 quadrilateral
5 pentagon
6 hexagon
7 heptagon
8 octagon
9 nonagon
10 decagon

This polygon has 66 sides, so it is called a hexagon.
